Situation1: They are expected to be present at a family dinner or small gathering.
Expectation2: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation2: The Mother Superior has asked the nun to lead a series of daily reflections for the entire community during an upcoming retreat.
Story:
I stared at my phone, the message from my stepmother glowing on the screen: “Family dinner this Sunday. It would mean a lot if you could come.” I could almost hear her hopeful tone, the way she always tried to make me feel included, even though I still sometimes felt like an outsider at the table. My stepbrother had already texted, “You better not bail this time.” I knew how much these gatherings mattered to them, how much they wanted me to be part of their world.

But in my other world, the convent halls were quiet, filled with the scent of old wood and candle wax. Mother Superior had just asked me to lead the daily reflections for our upcoming retreat—a responsibility I’d never held before. She’d looked at me with such trust, expecting me to guide the sisters in prayer and contemplation, to be present in spirit and mind.

The two expectations pressed in on me, heavy and unyielding. I wanted to be there for my family, to show them I cared. But I also wanted to honor my commitment to my sisters, to serve as I’d promised. My heart ached as I realized I couldn’t be fully present in both places at once.
